content: "http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/03/03/1818234.aspx" Today Sen. John McCain failed in his effort to strip thousands on earmarks from a government funding bill moving through Congress. His amendment would also have reduced the funding for several government departments to last year's lower spending levels. His amendment failed 63-32, with a simple majority needed for passage. Only two Democrats voted with McCain: Evan Bayh and Claire McCaskill. There were eight Republicans who voted against McCain, thereby supporting the earmarks and the higher levels of spending. All but one of those Republicans (Snowe) sit on the Senate Appropriations Committee. That panel is tasked with writing the spending bills and are best positioned to add earmarks. Those GOP committee members voting against McCain were Bennett, Bond, Cochran, Collins, Murkowski, Shelby and Specter. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
reply: "http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/03/03/1818234.aspx" Today Sen. John McCain failed in his effort to strip thousands on earmarks from a government funding bill moving through Congress. His amendment would also have reduced the funding for several government departments to last year's lower spending levels. His amendment failed 63-32, with a simple majority needed for passage. Only two Democrats voted with McCain: Evan Bayh and Claire McCaskill. There were eight Republicans who voted against McCain, thereby supporting the earmarks and the higher levels of spending. All but one of those Republicans (Snowe) sit on the Senate Appropriations Committee. That panel is tasked with writing the spending bills and are best positioned to add earmarks. Those GOP committee members voting against McCain were Bennett, Bond, Cochran, Collins, Murkowski, Shelby and Specter. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
title: MCCAIN EARMARKS AMENDMENT FAILS

content: "http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/03/mccain-loses-fight-over-earmarks/?hp" Mr. McCain, Republican of Arizona and a longtime foe of pet projects tucked into spending bills, has been bashing the bill under consideration — a $410 billion omnibus spending proposal — that would finance governmental spending through Sept. 30 of this year. The amendment that was just rejected would have jettisoned the omnibus bill and frozen spending levels. The Senate will continue debating the omnibus bill throughout much of this week; Republicans are pointing to overlap between the $787 billion stimulus package of a few weeks ago and spending provisions for some agencies in this carryover bill. Even Mr. McCain wasn’t optimistic this morning that his proposal had a shot, despite his efforts to juxtapose the dire straits of the American economy with a seemingly endless list of earmarks ranging from improving blueberry production in Georgia to financing a study of pig odor in Iowa. Again today, he called for President Obama to veto the omnibus spending bill once it’s passed, to take out his veto pen. “The last guy should’ve taken out his veto pen,” Mr. McCain said of former President Bush, without mentioning his name. “He should’ve. He didn’t and he lost the confidence of the American people because we’re not careful stewards of the taxpayers’ dollars.” Taxpayers for Common Sense, a nonpartisan group, has calculated the top earmarkers – those who have garnered the highest number (in dollar value) of projects. Senator Robert Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, leads the list among those specifically requested by individual lawmakers. Two Democrats, Senators Evan Bayh of Indiana and Claire McCaskill of Missouri, voted with 30 Republicans for the amendment. Ms. McCaskill, a prolific user of Twitter, wrote this: “Voted yes on McCain amendment. Awkward when I disagree with party leadership but I really think McCain is right on this one.” Senator McCain’s tweets today so far list another Top Ten list of earmarks. (He’s been sending out lists for several days. Today’s so far includes: *$819, 000 for catfish genetics research in Alabama *$190,000 for the Buffalo Bill Historical Center in Cody, Wyo. *$400,000 for copper wire theft prevention efforts *$47,500 to remodel and expand a playground in Ottawa, Ill. *$209,000 for blueberry production in Georgia… *$285,000 for the Discovery Center of Idaho in Boise "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

title: MCCAIN EARMARKS AMENDMENT FAILS

content: "http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/02/the-top-10-list-of-earmarkers/" According to the spreadsheet, Mr. Cochran had a hand in 204 earmarks worth nearly $471 million in federal spending, with 65 of those earmarks worth nearly $77 million requested specifically by him. Analyzed a different way, Senator Robert C. Byrd Jr., Democrat of West Virginia, takes the prize for top earmarker, with nearly $123 million in special projects included in the bill specifically at his request, out of a total of nearly $152 million that he requested in conjunction with other officials. Mr. Byrd, the senior member of the Senate, was chairman of the Appropriations Committee until the end of last year. A number of senators make the top 10 list regardless of which way it is sorted. In no particular order, they included: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, the new chairman of the Appropriations Committee; Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama; Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California; Senator Christopher S. Bond, Republican of Missouri; and Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa. The Republican leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, makes the top 10 for the number of projects requested specifically by him, with 36 earmarks worth more than $51 million. But using the broader measure of Mr. McConnell’s overall involvement in more than $75.5 million in earmarks, puts him toward the middle of the pack. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

Maybe he wants to run again witch would be ok with me, but I would not vote him or another rep until they realize the jig is up and this American is not falling for it unless they offer real change to this nation like the FairTax. Enough is enough. Reps offer meaningful change to the American people...not the same old song and dance mmyyy friend... I wish more people would realize this and not take party line just because beliefs are more to one side or the other...because where the tire meets the dirt...they are both the same.

content: Anbar - You left two Republicans out of your list ... you said 8, listed 7, and there were 9 ... Alexander and Snowe were the two you missed. There were also two Republicans "Not Voting" .... Sessions and Johanns. I figure that those voting against the amendment ... and not voting ... had their snouts pretty deep in the trough. The "pork" splits about 60/40, Dem/Rep ... about right for a majority/minority split. I'm Republican (though I'm fast losing my taste for the "Grand Ole Party" and may soon join my husband as an Independent) and am getting more than a tad tired of hearing Republicans give a good sermon on Sunday, then turn around and sin with the best of them. Where I'm from, when a pastor does that, he loses his congregation. POTUS 44 would make huge points with me if he lived up to his words and vetoed this porkfest.

content: quote: I'm Republican (though I'm fast losing my taste for the "Grand Ole Party" and may soon join my husband as an Independent) and am getting more than a tad tired of hearing Republicans give a good sermon on Sunday, then turn around and sin with the best of them. Where I'm from, when a pastor does that, he loses his congregation. I have now heard it directly from the horses mouth. If you are active in your party..please send this message to them...real change next time if they want the middle to come thier way or I will contine to play the game and vote dem again until they have had enough...seems like they would have had enough by now. Other than that it's smoke and mirroes like always. In more poetic terms: Go tell the Spartans, thou that passest by, That here, obedient to their laws, we lie. Countries from the first till now, Are born from stern to bow. By men and women who sacrifice, In the world of heat and ice. Knowing from right and wrong, Knowing our national song. So our family can live free, And strangers can honor and see. Built a nation of many tongues, A unified language is how it's run. Respect the past where we came, Americans now we are all the same. We still fight and give our life, Father, mother, husband and wife. So our country will smile and sometimes cry, Never in vain shall Americans die. Go tell the Spartans, thou that passest by, That here, obedient to their laws, we lie By, Dr. Dennis J. Malone please tell them.....thank you.

content: I'm neither a Republican, nor a Democrat but an Indpendent who voted for Obama. As for Senator McCain's efforts to pass this amendment to strip earmarks from the bill, kudos to him! He is fighting an uphill battle (anti-earmarks) but he is continuing the fight.He deserves A for effort and kudos for sticking to his principles. Jack
reply: I'm neither a Republican, nor a Democrat but an Indpendent who voted for Obama. As for Senator McCain's efforts to pass this amendment to strip earmarks from the bill, kudos to him! He is fighting an uphill battle (anti-earmarks) but he is continuing the fight.He deserves A for effort and kudos for sticking to his principles. Jack

content: Not surprising, another "maverick from Arizona" gave the people a clear picture of the hazards of entering the Vietnam war with greater force and how to secure the south with military "air" power. He was soundly defeated in the Presidential election of 1964 and then to watch Johnson open the theater to far greater number of manpower and cost, almost exactly of was prescribed. A month earlier Johnson version of the Tonkin attack was published by the media and gained an almost frantic stampede for revenge of North Vietamese horde. Only three Senators of the 535 legislatures voted against the resolution. Senator Barry Goldwater didn't mix too many words. He said if you're going into a fight give it everything you got. Where Johnson had promised restrictions and no body bags. Of course that was far from what happened and Johnson didn't run for a second elected term. Another thing Senator Goldwater didn't not favor, Johnson's spending spree on domestic fronts, indebtness to welfare recepients and BIG government. It might have secured Congressional reelection for his party for thirty years but set a precedent that was hard to break. Similar to what we seeing today.

content: If you total up the money involved in all the earmarks that benefit Republicans and Democrats the money going to 40 Republicans is almost identical(actually slightly more) than the amount going to 57 Democrats. Neither party has any business wagging its fingers and scolding only the other party for pork barrel spending.

Enough is enough. Reps offer meaningful change to the American people...not the same old song and dance mmyyy friend... I wish more people would realize this and not take party line just because beliefs are more to one side or the other...because where the tire meets the dirt...they are both the same. At least McCain was honest up front and told the people like it was and still is.......I like honesty, not a pack of promises. Changing parties does not mean change, especially now, there are no longer any checks and balances under a 'complete' one party domination. Would it not have been better to vote just for a different man, a man that put it straight forward? And what exactly was McCain honest about? In fact, what exactly did he say? Other than a slightly watered down version of GW Bush. Christ almighty, he even back peddled on torture.
reply: Barry said we'd be out of Iraq in 18 months I remember, leaving 50,000 troops behind is NOT getting out of Iraq. It's entrampment, another Diem bein Phu. McCain said the opposite............he new it would and it will take longer. But everyone believed the Military Stratigist "Messiah" instead. Don't send a boy to do a man's job.
title: MCCAIN EARMARKS AMENDMENT FAILS

content: Just remember that one man's "Earmark" or "Pork" is the next man's Prime Rib roast. Somebody somewhere had to believe that the project labeled as "pork" was important enough to attach to the pending bill. That earmark is going to help a group of people somewhere.
